item.title: Designing a Research Folder Structure That Scales
item.dc:creator: Linda K. Sg.
item.description:
Status: Completed

Context:
This entry documents the design and finalization of a modular research folder structure intended for projects that evolve over time, rather than projects optimized solely to terminate in a single paper. The motivation was to reduce long-term cognitive overhead and improve traceability across heterogeneous research activities.

The guiding principle is deliberately simple:
separate thinking, data, code, and evidence early and explicitly.

Structure Overview

The system is organized into three tiers, each mapped to a realistic research workload rather than an abstract ideal.

Basic

For literature-driven work and small academic or exploratory projects.

Standard

For master-level research and publication-oriented analysis.

Advanced

For doctoral and multi-year research with experiment tracking, versioning, and reproducibility requirements.

Design Rationale

The emphasis is not on folder count, but on decision clarity.

  • Raw data remains immutable
  • Manuscripts are modular rather than monolithic
  • Code is reproducible rather than exploratory residue
  • Experiments leave a traceable and auditable record

A well-designed structure is not administrative overhead.
It functions as cognitive infrastructure.

Outcome

This setup reduces friction when switching between projects, revisiting old analyses, preparing manuscripts or proposals, and scaling collaboration or solo work.

No specific tooling is enforced.
LaTeX, JabRef, Git, Python, and R integrate naturally, but none are mandatory.

Net effect: less time managing artifacts, more time allocated to actual research.

Next Steps

Use this structure as the backbone for long-horizon computational biology projects, particularly those involving iterative modeling, multi-modal data, and evolving hypotheses.

Related Documentation

A longer, practitioner-oriented explanation and a ready-to-use template version of this folder structure are documented separately:

https://lk01sg.gumroad.com/l/sf-riset-advanced

item.title: Notes on Phenotypic Screening and System-Level Drug Discovery
item.dc:creator: Linda K. Sg.
item.description:
Context: This entry emerged from ongoing reading and synthesis around phenotypic screening, polypharmacology, and system-level failure modes in drug discovery. The immediate trigger was revisiting historical drug examples alongside recent critiques of contemporary screening paradigms, particularly concerns that many failures reflect model mismatch rather than purely technical shortcomings (Vincent & Gianni, 2025; Lowe, 2025).

Process Notes:

  • Compared classical phenotypic discoveries (e.g., aspirin, metformin, sirolimus) with contemporary target-first workflows
  • Integrated perspectives from systems biology, cancer resistance literature, and network pharmacology.
  • Noted recurring patterns where translational failure appears rooted in abstraction choices and assay framing, rather than insufficient molecular resolution alone.

Open Questions:

  • How can network-level or phenotypic readouts be standardized without collapsing back into reductionist proxies?
  • What experimental designs best support causal inference when integrating phenotypic screens with multi-omics data?
  • Where should industry draw the boundary between exploratory system interrogation and pipeline efficiency pressures?

Next Steps:

  • Explore concrete case studies combining phenotypic screening with single-cell or spatial omics.
  • Examine internal decision criteria used by industry teams when selecting between target-first and phenotype-first discovery paradigms.

This entry documents an evolving reasoning process rather than a finalized position, serving as groundwork for potential future project development.

Related Essay:
Phenotypic Screening as System Interrogation

References / Reading Trail

  1. Vincent, F., & Gianni, D. (2025). The limitations of small molecule and genetic screening in phenotypic drug discovery. Cell Chemical Biology, 32(11), 1310–1320. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.chembiol.2025.10.008

  2. Lowe, D. (2025, Nov 18). Thinking about running a phenotypic assay? In The Pipeline, Science/AAAS. https://www.science.org/content/blog-post/thinking-about-running-phenotypic-assay
